dialogues.Ramsey:
[1]		Who found her?  	Cole nods at a visibly shaken WORKMAN seated in a patrol car.  
[2]		Well, honey, what's worse?  Doing it 		yourself or asking your mother for help? 			 		Can it wait 'til I get back/ 			 		I have no idea, Jeannie.  	Novak checks his watch and the street.  Clearly waiting for 	someone or something.  
[3]		Well all right.  Good luck with the 		Monster.  I love you too.  Bye-bye.  	Ramsey snaps shut the cell-phone.  
[4]		We call Jeannie's mother "The Monster" 		because, well... she just is.  	Novak is oblivious, pouring over tire-related info.  
[5]		I know you could care less about my 		personal life, Peter, but I do 		appreciate the occasional, "How's your 		wife, Gordon?"  	He waits.  Novak obliges:  
[6]		Pregnant.  Thanks for asking.  	Novak is distracted by Teddy Lee entering the diner.

[8]		I feel for those girls too, Pete.  And 		their families.  But it's just a job. 		Someday it'll be over.  And then what'll 		you have?  	Much to Novak's appreciation, Teddy Lee's arrival provides an 	escape from answering the question.  
[9]			 		More hair.  I could knit this guy a 		toupee.  	Novak finds something in the report that catches him by 	surprise.  He double-checks and shows the item to Teddy.  
[10]		And that means?  	Teddy moves aside and takes another bite of his lunch 	.

[12]		Breeders typically destroy albino pups, 		so this animal is truly unique.  
[13]		Registered breeders of German Shepherds.  	The list is long and a few of the cops GROAN.  Novak silences 	them with a fierce look that says, "I will not rest until 	this man is found and neither should you."  
[14]		She was still living at home?

[17]		She remembers because it was her "dream 		truck."  Wanted one just like it.  
[18]		Let's give old Carl a call.  Tell him 		he's got company.

[20]			 		You should come downstairs.  
[21]		What the hell does that mean?

[23]		Whoa.  Wait a minute.  
[24]		We'll go back to his house, Pete. 		There's still a lot to do.  Analyze the 		videos, track sales of the bleach, go 		through his records.  Maybe he owns 		property somewhere.  
[25]		Is it possible?  
[26]		You sure you want to go through with 		this?  
[27]		I don't know, Pete, but for god's 		sake... This is nuts.  Do you really 		understand what they're going to do?  
[28]		Why jeopardize what we've already done? 		We caught the sonofabitch.  Carl 		Stargher.  That's going to be like 		Bundy, Gacy, Dahmer.  A case that makes 		careers.  But if we push our luck.  If 		this is all bullshit and we come out 		smelling like it.

[33]		What happens here?  
[34]		Where the hell you been?  	They turn to see Ramsey.  
[35]		Next time, tell me, okay?

[37]		Jesus Christ, man, you look like hell.  
[38]		Whoa-whoa-whoa.  Mind telling me what 		the fuck is happening?  	 Novak points to the photo of Stargher's basement, 	specifically the hoist.  
[39]		You're bettin' the farm on something you 		saw after they pumped you full of god 		knows-what kind of shit?

What if this is all some 		kind of trick your head is playing on 		you?  	He won't consider that.  Novak climbs into the helicopter and 	buckles himself in.  He looks to Ramsey - you coming? - 	Ramsey pats the side of the chopper and signals for the pilot 	to take off.  
[42]		What are you talking about?  	Miriam analyzes the situation and regretfully, angrily, 	worriedly realizes what's happened.  
[43]		Done what?

[42] 	Small and isolated, the nearest neighbor a block away.  
[43] 	The place is a mess.  Computer print-outs, dirty dishes, 	unopened mail, videotapes, and notepads cover tables, chairs 	and floor.  On the crammed bookshelves, psychology texts sit 	next to volumes on mythology, religion, and the occult. 	Totems, figurines and artifacts (Central and South American 	in origin) adorn the walls and tables.  	As Portishead plays on the stereo, we find Catherine 	suffering from insomnia, wearing goofy-yet-hip eyeglasses, 	sweatpants and a UCSD T-shirt, sharing a late-night snack 	with her pet CAT.  She shuts the refrigerator door and we 	linger on an odd POSTCARD taped to the surface.  A kitschy 	postcard of a warrior/goddess.  
[44] 	Lying on her bed , Catherine sleepily stares at 	the ceiling, rolls onto her side, and feels herself drawn 	into the comforter.  The folds of the fabric become ripples. 	Ripples become dunes.  
[45] 	IN HER OWN BED, Catherine's eyes are open.  In sharp contrast 	to a typical reaction to a nightmare, she remains calm.  No 	sweaty face, no gasp, no reaction at all, really.  She might 	as well have been dreaming of puppy dogs.  Wide awake, her 	eyes return their gaze to the ceiling.  
[46]		Go.  To.  Sleep.  
[47]		It's fixed!  	AT THE TREE TRUNK, Catherine extends her hand and suddenly 	Edward is there, quite close, reaching out.  Catherine's hand 	trembles.  The boy is startled.
